questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a rash and difficulty breathing after being administered penicillin. Which of the following types of hypersensitivity reactions is most likely responsible for her symptoms according to the Gell and Coombs classification?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Examples

Type I (Immediate)

(Option A)

IgE-mediated reactions, leading to mast cell degranulation and histamine release.

Examples include allergic rhinitis and anaphylaxis.

Type II (Cytotoxic)

(Option B)

Mediated by IgG or IgM antibodies directed against antigens on cell surfaces or matrix, causing cell lysis.

Conditions include autoimmune hemolytic anemia and rheumatic fever.

Type III (Immune Complex)

(Option C)

Caused by the formation of antigen-antibody complexes that deposit in tissues, leading to inflammation.

Examples include systemic lupus erythematosus and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

Type IV (Delayed)

(Option D)

Mediated by T cells, occurring hours to days after exposure to an antigen.

Seen in contact dermatitis and tuberculin reactions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old healthcare worker develops a red, itchy rash on her hands two days after using a new brand of latex gloves. She reports no immediate reaction at the time of exposure, but 48 hours later, she noticed redness, swelling, and itching at the site of contact. She has no known history of allergies or similar reactions in the past. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is most likely responsible for her symptoms?

A 28-year-old woman with a history of asthma experiences severe wheezing, shortness of breath, and facial swelling minutes after accidentally ingesting peanuts. She is treated promptly in the emergency department with epinephrine, antihistamines, and corticosteroids, and her symptoms improve. However, 8 hours later, she began to develop increased chest tightness and wheezing, requiring additional medical intervention. Which of the following best explains her delayed respiratory symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Incomplete clearance of histamine from the bloodstream

options.label: B
options.text: Continuous allergen exposure leading to sustained mast cell degranulation

options.label: C
options.text: Recruitment of eosinophils and other inflammatory cells, causing a delayed inflammatory response

options.label: D
options.text: Development of IgG antibodies against the allergen, causing a delayed hypersensitivity reaction

questions.correct_answer: C. Recruitment of eosinophils and other inflammatory cells, causing a delayed inflammatory response

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman develops sudden hives, facial swelling, and shortness of breath after taking an antibiotic. She is rushed to the emergency room, where she receives epinephrine and improves quickly. Which of the following hypersensitivity reactions best explains her symptoms ?
questions.explanation:
Phase

Timing

Mechanism

Clinical Features

Early Phase

Seconds to minutes

Mast cell/basophil degranulation: IgE cross-linking leads to the release of histamine and other mediators.

Skin: Urticaria (hives), itching (pruritus), erythema (redness), localized angioedema (swelling around lips, eyes)

Respiratory: Bronchoconstriction leading to wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, sneezing, nasal congestion (allergic rhinitis)

Cardiovascular: Vasodilation and hypotension (drop in blood pressure), dizziness, syncope (fainting)

Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea due to smooth muscle contraction

Systemic Reaction: Anaphylaxis in severe cases, with generalized urticaria, angioedema, severe hypotension, and respiratory distress (life-threatening)

Late Phase

4–12 hours, peaks at 24–48 hours, lasting up to days

Inflammatory cell recruitment: Cytokines/chemokines attract eosinophils, neutrophils, and macrophages, causing sustained inflammation.

Skin: Persistent redness, swelling, intense itching, and development of an eczema-like rash (seen in atopic dermatitis)

Respiratory: Recurrent bronchoconstriction, prolonged wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, mucus production, and airway hyperresponsiveness (chronic asthma exacerbation)

Eyes: Persistent redness and irritation in conjunctiva (allergic conjunctivitis)

Chronic Changes: In prolonged or recurrent reactions, there may be tissue remodeling, fibrosis, and thickening of affected areas (e.g., airways in asthma, skin in chronic dermatitis)

Type

Mechanism

Clinical Features

Onset

Type I Early

IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation

Hives, swelling, respiratory distress

Immediate (minutes)

Type I Delayed

IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation

Wheezing, chest tightness, localized itching

(Option B ruled out)

Hours to days

Type II

Antibody-mediated cell destruction

Hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia

Delayed (hours to days)

Type III

Immune complex deposition

Joint pain, fever, vasculitis

(Option C ruled out)

Delayed (hours to days)

Type IV

T-cell mediated response

Skin rash, contact dermatitis

(Option D ruled out)

Delayed (48-72 hours)

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy experiences facial swelling, hives, and difficulty breathing after accidentally eating a peanut cookie. He is treated with epinephrine and antihistamines and stabilizes, but later develops wheezing and difficulty breathing. Which pair of Type I hypersensitivity reactions best explains his experience?

options.label: D
options.text: Allergic rhinitis followed by food allergy

questions.correct_answer: A. Anaphylaxis followed by allergic asthma
questions.explanation:
Condition

Trigger

Early Phase Symptoms

Late Phase Symptoms

Anaphylaxis

Foods (e.g., peanuts, shellfish), insect stings, medications (e.g., penicillin)

Sudden onset of hives, facial swelling, difficulty breathing, low blood pressure, rapid progression to shock

Persistent wheezing, chest tightness, difficulty breathing, sustained low blood pressure; can last hours after initial exposure

Allergic Rhinitis (Hay Fever)

Pollen, dust mites, pet dander

Sneezing, itchy and watery eyes, runny nose, nasal congestion

Prolonged nasal congestion, sinus pressure, and coughing due to postnasal drip

Allergic Asthma

Pollen, mold, animal dander, air pollutants

Coughing, wheezing, chest tightness, shortness of breath

Persistent wheezing, chest tightness, and airway hyperresponsiveness lead to chronic symptoms if untreated

Food Allergy

Common allergens include peanuts, tree nuts, eggs, milk, seafood

Hives, itching, swelling of lips/face, nausea, abdominal pain, vomiting, and, in severe cases, anaphylaxis

Persistent abdominal pain, diarrhea, skin rash (eczema) in some chronic cases, worsening of asthma or other respiratory symptoms

Atopic Dermatitis (Eczema)

Environmental allergens, certain foods, skin irritants

Red, itchy rash, often in flexural areas (e.g., inside elbows, behind knees)

Chronic dry, thickened skin due to scratching, possible development of secondary infections due to skin barrier breakdown

Urticaria (Hives)

Foods, medications, insect stings, temperature changes

Raised, red, itchy welts (hives) on the skin, can appear within minutes of exposure

If chronic, repeated episodes of itching and welts lasting hours to days after initial exposure

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient receives an iodine-based contrast agent for a CT scan. Within minutes, she develops hives, facial swelling, and difficulty breathing. She reports no prior allergies to iodine or contrast agents. Which of the following best describes her reaction and its mechanism?

options.label: A
options.text: Anaphylaxis, caused by IgE-mediated mast cell activation

options.label: C
options.text: Anaphylactoid reaction, caused by direct mast cell activation without IgE

options.label: D
options.text: Anaphylactoid reaction, requiring prior exposure for mast cell sensitization

questions.correct_answer: C. Anaphylactoid reaction, caused by direct mast cell activation without IgE
questions.explanation:
Feature

Anaphylaxis

Anaphylactoid Reaction

Mechanism

IgE-mediated (Type I hypersensitivity)

Non-IgE mediated (direct mast cell activation)

Prior Sensitization Needed

Yes

No (Option D ruled out)

Trigger

Specific allergens (e.g., foods, insect stings)

Direct stimuli (e.g., radiocontrast, opioids)

First-Line Treatment

Epinephrine

Epinephrine

Additional Symptoms

Hives, swelling, respiratory distress, hypotension

Same as anaphylaxis

Examples

Peanuts, shellfish, penicillin

Radiocontrast dyes, NSAIDs, opioids

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the ER with coughing up blood and difficulty breathing. He's scared and tells you he's never had symptoms like this before. Lab results reveal he has antibodies against the basement membrane in his lungs and kidneys. His immune system is attacking these tissues, and cell destruction is being triggered through a specific mechanism. Which of the following best explains what's happening inside his body?

options.label: A
options.text: Antigen-specific IgE binding to mast cells

options.label: B
options.text: Antibody binding to cell surface antigens with complement activation

options.label: C
options.text: Immune complexes depositing in blood vessels

questions.correct_answer: B. Antibody binding to cell surface antigens with complement activation

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with fatigue, jaundice, and shortness of breath. Laboratory tests reveal a hemoglobin level of 7.2 g/dL, elevated bilirubin, and a positive direct Coombs test. Peripheral blood smear shows spherocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and its corresponding type of hypersensitivity?

A 30-year-old woman presents with joint pain, fever, and a malar rash. Laboratory tests show proteinuria, low complement levels, and the presence of anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) and anti-dsDNA antibodies. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the pathology of her disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct binding of IgE to mast cells, leading to histamine release

options.label: B
options.text: Antibody-mediated cytotoxicity targeting red blood cell antigens

options.label: C
options.text: Deposition of immune complexes in tissues

options.label: D
options.text: T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity targeting self-antigens on tissue cells

questions.correct_answer: C. Deposition of immune complexes in tissues

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a recent history of sore throat, followed by dark-colored urine, facial swelling, and high blood pressure. Laboratory findings show proteinuria, hematuria, and elevated anti-streptolysin O (ASO) titers. Which of the following best describes the patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Examples

Type I (Immediate)

IgE-mediated reactions, leading to mast cell degranulation and histamine release.

Examples include allergic rhinitis and anaphylaxis.

Type II (Cytotoxic)

Mediated by IgG or IgM antibodies directed against antigens on cell surfaces or matrix, causing cell lysis.

Conditions include autoimmune hemolytic anemia and rheumatic fever.

Type III (Immune Complex)

Caused by the formation of antigen-antibody complexes that deposit in tissues, leading to inflammation.

Examples include systemic lupus erythematosus and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

Type IV (Delayed)

Mediated by T cells, occurring hours to days after exposure to an antigen.

Seen in contact dermatitis and tuberculin reactions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a red, itchy rash on his hands that developed two days after using a new pair of latex gloves. Physical examination reveals erythematous, scaly patches on both hands. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of this patient’s condition, a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Activation of IgE antibodies bound to mast cells

options.label: C
options.text: Direct binding of antibodies to cell surface antigens

questions.correct_answer: D. Activation of sensitized T cells

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a rash on his arms and neck that developed several days after he worked in his garden, where he handled several plants. He mentions he has never had a rash before but recently experienced severe itching and redness in the affected areas. A patch test reveals an allergic reaction to a specific plant resin. What type of hypersensitivity does it represent?
